data.title: Fix crash when running a game with the profiler enabled
data.body:
NativeScriptLanguage::profiling_get_accumulated_data and NativeScriptLanguage::profiling_get_frame_data were returning a negative value and that made a crash on ScriptDebuggerRemote::_send_profiling_data, since the value was added to the ofs and then it was trying to access profile_info at a negative index.
Closes #10157

data.title: Visual Script CallInstance should create an Instance when none is set
data.body:
# Issue
Ok I'm taking a look at the Visual Scripting to make some videos about it. Something I found very problematic is that you can't use an instance to make a simple call without having to instance it before, and there is no way to do.

That's how I would do it in GDScript
```GDScript
extends Node
func _ready():
    var t = Tween.new()
    print(t)
```

Currently, I couldn't find a way to do this using Visual Script.

# Solution (?)
Since the CallInstance node already has everything available to do an instance call, I think it would be good to let it create an instance by default using the `Base Type` and passing this object in the `pass` output. 

E.g. this setup would be the same as the above example

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10171059/29093451-465093ba-7c60-11e7-8c9c-8b367fa4b19e.png)

The problem is that currently the `instance` input of this node is always null if another node doesn't pass a object output to it. And there is no way to set a value to it in the Inspector, so...as I said, I can't think of a way to have this working.

# Real Life problems
This totally screw the workflow of a team of a programmer and a designer since the designer can't call a function from a GDScript created by the programmer... neither can we extend a Visual Scripting using class inheritance and making it inherits the GDScript created by the programmer, neither can we just make an instance call using the GDScript as `Base Script` of the CallInstance node. So thi won't work.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10171059/29093749-4fb8e5a0-7c61-11e7-8a2f-9f4166181671.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10171059/29093759-5784b368-7c61-11e7-9e83-4b47a64d5e26.png)

data.title: Fix freeze on close of game using 2D physics introduced by #9832
data.body:
Additionally, port the fix to 3D physics, just in case.

Not completely sure why the code was written that way, though I can confirm that freezes go away with my patch. I just copy-pasted the code from area_set_space.

Seems done properly for 2.1.

data.title: glTF Importer does not properly handle camera export from Blender
data.body:
**OS - Godot version:** Arch Linux - master [`8a4bce6`](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/8a4bce6ebd843f9a8f482f74601f4933aae737a3)


**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Godot does not properly handle the importing of glTF files from blender with camera included. Using the  Khronos [glTF Exporter](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter) for Blender.


**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a new mesh in blender, then export as a glTF. When exporting, tick "Export camera".

data.title: removed calls to cursor_set_visible on all platforms fixes #10167
Get a pixel array from a draw_line method
data.body:
I've been playing with a little texture editor and managed to make a pretty quick and nifty draw method to draw freehand lines.

It uses the draw_line method to interpolate between points created by the mouse pointer

It's all fun and games until I try to commit the pixels to an image texture image, using the put_pixel() method.

That method needs an x and a y floating point for every pixel. So I need all the pixels from the draw_line method I used.

My strategy is to commit the pixels every time a new line is created- and only commit pixels of the last drawn line - upon mouse release.

I can't implement it unless I have the array of pixels created by a draw_line method.

I know I could use screen capture to do this, but it would be soo wasteful to screen cap the entire canvas

data.title: Core/io: Fix typo in resource_format_binary
ResourceImporterScene: fix 'bult' typo
Added missing descriptions to Vector2 methods abs and clamped
Better default values for default environment and default material metallic
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Win10 current Godot3 build


**Issue description:**
ISSUE1 - The default world environment that is loaded into each new scene (default_env.tres) has the ambient_light_sky_contribution = 0.0 value. This means that any meshes that are added to the scene with high roughness values will be seen as black. This value should be default at 1. I am fairly sure that this changed not too long ago!

This is particularly problematic when using separate scenes for objects that will be instanced into a master scene. In these separate scenes, you currently have to add a new environment just to setup a material, then hide it when it is instanced into a master scene

This is currently what we get:

![default_env](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29054427-7e039c16-7c39-11e7-8922-9f8e3e04aad2.jpg)

This what it should be:

![fixed_env](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29054435-8ad6f7ee-7c39-11e7-9e3a-c7946fc98f56.jpg)

ISSUE2: The default metallic value for a spatial material is currently 0.1. Most materials will be either a metal (1) or dielectric (0), so having 0.1 is confusing for someone new to the engine, as they may think it is a good default value. 

The default should be either 0 or 1. The advantage of having it at 0 is that materials are more likely to be non-metallic (dielectric) than metallic, so may serve as a better starting point. Also having both metallic and roughness at default 0 gives a pleasing result for a material, as seen below:

![material0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29054785-a7197704-7c3b-11e7-84d7-197d44649d0c.jpg)


The advantage to having it at 1 as default is that when adding maps, this value needs to be changed to 1 anyway. However the same would apply to the roughness value and if both of these were at a default of 1, then the default material shows as all black and is not a good starting point, as seen below:

![material1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29054796-b4170d90-7c3b-11e7-8281-bc57d1e7c525.jpg)



**Steps to reproduce:**


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Triplanar mapping is working in world space only
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Win10 current build of Godot 3


**Issue description:**
The triplanar mapping uv option in the spatial material works well but only in global space. This means that when an object is moved or rotated, the texture changes. This can be useful in some situations, such as many instances of the same static object (such as a rock), where the global space would automatically give each instance a unique mapping.

Most times you need more control, and a local space option would be more suitable. This means that anywhere you place the instanced mesh it retains the same mapping/appearance. Also would make the triplanar suitable for a moving mesh.

Also, the current offset controls do not work.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Add the triplanar uv option to a material and move the mesh around. The mapping does not stick to the object.

Also, try adjusting the offset controls. They currently do not work. 


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: AO maps behaving incorrectly in spatial material
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Windows 10, current build of Godot 3

**Issue description:**
When using a custom AO map in the spatial material, it is either not visible at all (with omni lights) or very faint (with mesh lights and GIprobe)

**Steps to reproduce:**

Add an AO map to a material on a mesh. Add some omni lights. In this image, the crate on the left has no AO map, but the one on the right does. There is no visible difference.

![ao_issue_omni](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29053371-1829f62a-7c33-11e7-9f4d-3a57c54cd1b4.jpg)

If this same scene has lights turned off and 2 mesh lights (luminant materials) and Giprobe added. The crate on left has the AO map, and this time it is visible but very faint.

![ao_issue_gi](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/29053390-3cfaa788-7c33-11e7-9f9b-f90ea9fad1be.jpg)

There does seem to be an issue with using lights and AO map. Turning on the effect light in environment makes no difference, and I think this only effects SSAO objects and not custom AO mapped objects.

Would be very useful to have a multiplier for the AO, so that when there is a faint AO effect, it could be dialed up to taste!


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

[ao_map_issue.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1206731/ao_map_issue.zip)

data.title: Scripts Not Added to Instanced Scenes
data.body:
_**bugsquad edit**_: reproduction steps which were used to confirm the issue are here: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10156#issuecomment-320997658 

-----------

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
OS: Windows
Godot Version: 3.0 Alpha Build 1

**Issue description:**
I have found a problem where when I add a script to a scene, all nodes that instance that scene don't get the script.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Make a scene that you will instance.
2. Instance that scene into the scene your game will run.
3. Add a script to the original scene.

data.title: GDQuery: expansion of '$' functionality for JQuery-esque simulation of node hierarchy?
data.body:
So I'm looking at [`modules/gdscript/gd_parser.cpp`](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/modules/gdscript/gd_parser.cpp), lines 259-350, and I'm thinking to myself, why can't we just also make it possible to do an open/close parentheses with a single variant parameter as a way to do a function call for JQuery-esque selector syntax for accessing nodes in the node hierarchy? Wouldn't that make Godot a LOT more powerful for acquiring and comparing groups of nodes? In fact, it's probably the ONLY engine that could do this effectively.

Example syntax off the top of my head:
(note, these would all return a specialized Array type where attempts to get/set a property or execute a method NOT associated with the custom Array type would instead attempt to do that on the first item of the array)

- $(self): executes relative to the current script
- $(node_reference): executes relative to the given node
- $("#name"): equivalent to `get_node("name")`
- $("Button"): captures into an array all nodes derived from the Button type
- $("CustomButton"): First searches for a built-in type by the name CustomButton. After that fails, it searches through local / member variables of the current script for something called "CustomButton". If that fails, it throws an error. If it succeeds, then it preloads the value of that variable looking for a script resource (.gd, .vs, .cs, .gdns). If it finds it, then it will capture into an array all nodes derived from the CustomButton type
- $("HBoxContainer Label"): captures all Label-derived nodes that are descendants of an HBoxContainer.
- $("HBoxContainer > Label"): captures all Label-derived nodes that are immediate children of an HBoxContainer.
- $("Node:cool"): captures all Node-derived nodes that have property "cool" set to true. If the property doesn't exist, or if it does exist, but is false, then it returns false. Otherwise true.
- $("Enemy~do_cool"): captures all Enemy-derived custom nodes that have a method do_cool.
- $("Node[prop=value]"): captures all Node-derived nodes with property "prop" that has value "value".
- $("Node.group_name"): captures all Node-derived nodes in the group "group_name".
- $("?#MyNode"): captures all nodes with the name "MyNode" *relative to the local scene root*.
- $("!Label"): captures all Label-derived nodes *relative to the global scene root*. (obviously, things like "#name" wouldn't work for instanced nodes in this scenario)
- $("!"): equivalent to get_tree().get_root()

I do get that this functionality may not be desired as part of the main GDScript module and possibly preferred as a plugin. If that is the case, then it would be nice if the engine made allowances for plugins to define global variables / functions, so that something like this could be done with G(...) or what-have-you.

data.title: Optionally limit exported ints/floats to positive/negative
data.body:
This is just a minor QoL improvement - it'd be nice to have an export hint for `int` and `float` types that allows you to specify whether you'll only allow positive/negative values (including 0). I know the feature can be emulated with `export(int, 0, [large number])`, but then you're made to decide what constitutes an appropriately large upper bound or lower bound.

I'd like to propose a simple 'shortcut' in the following form:

`export([int/float], POS)` is effectively an alias for `export([int/float], 0, [int_max/float_max])`
Similarly, `export([int/float], NEG)` is effectively an alias for `export([int/float], [int_min/float_min], 0)`

This isn't a majorly important suggestion nor do I have any idea how easy or hard it would be to implement, but considering the amount of times I've wished I could say "I want this export field to be valid for any positive number" (namely with things like speed, size, et cetera) I figured I would make the suggestion.
